title: 113_hr1785
content:
The "Mountains to Sound Greenway National Heritage Area Act" establishes the Mountains to Sound Greenway National Heritage Area, defines key terms, and designates the area under the Secretary of the Interior. SEC. 3. DESIGNATION OF THE MOUNTAINS TO SOUND GREENWAY NATIONAL HERITAGE AREA. The Mountains to Sound Greenway National Heritage Area is established in King and Kittitas counties, as depicted on the map. The county commission can choose to be excluded. A local coordinating entity will be selected by the Secretary. SEC. 4. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The local coordinating entity must submit a proposed management plan for the Heritage Area within 3 years of the Act's enactment. The plan should integrate protection, enhancement, and interpretation of natural, cultural, historic, scenic, and recreational resources, consider State government plans, and include inventories of resources and related properties in the Heritage Area. The proposed management plan for the Heritage Area should include comprehensive policies, strategies, and recommendations for conservation, funding, management, and development. It should also describe agreed-upon actions by governments, private organizations, and individuals to protect natural, historical, and cultural resources. Additionally, the plan should outline implementation actions by the local coordinating entity to promote ongoing collaboration among partners for resource protection and restoration. The proposed management plan for the Heritage Area should include policies, strategies, and recommendations for conservation, funding, and development. It should outline specific commitments for the first five years of operation, coordination of Federal, State, and local programs, an interpretative plan, and be approved by county commissions before submission to the Secretary. The management plan for the Heritage Area must be reviewed and approved or disapproved by the Secretary within 180 days. The plan should represent diverse interests and be in line with established criteria. The management plan for the Heritage Area must be reviewed and approved within 180 days. The plan should involve public and governmental input and ensure protection of natural, historical, and cultural resources. If disapproved, the Secretary must notify the local coordinating entity in writing. The Secretary must approve or disapprove the revised management plan within 180 days. Any substantial amendments to the plan must also be reviewed and approved by the Secretary, as well as by the county. The amendment to the management plan must be reviewed and approved by county commissions before implementation. The Secretary may provide technical assistance to various entities. SEC. 5. EVALUATION; REPORTING. Within 10 years of this Act's enactment, the Secretary, in consultation with the Secretary of Agriculture, must evaluate the accomplishments of the Heritage Area and submit a report. The evaluation will assess the progress of the local coordinating entity in achieving the goals of the Heritage Area, analyze investments, and review the management structure and partnerships. The Secretary must evaluate the accomplishments, investments, management structure, and partnerships of the Heritage Area within 10 years of the Act's enactment. A report with recommendations for the National Park Service's future role will be submitted to the House and Senate Committees on Natural Resources and Energy. SEC. 6. LOCAL COORDINATING ENTITY. The local coordinating entity for the Heritage Area is responsible for preparing a management plan, submitting reports on expenses and income every five years, and making grants to various entities within the National Heritage Area. The National Heritage Area can enter agreements, hire staff with expertise, obtain funds, contract for goods/services, support activities, and assist local entities. The National Heritage Area supports organizations in implementing the management plan by carrying out programs, maintaining exhibits, developing recreational and educational opportunities, increasing public awareness, protecting historic sites, and ensuring consistency. The National Heritage Area supports organizations in implementing the management plan by ensuring clear signs, promoting partnerships, considering diverse interests, conducting public meetings semiannually, and submitting annual reports for Federal funds received. The local coordinating entity must submit an annual report to the Secretary detailing activities, expenses, and income, make records available for audit, and ensure organizations receiving funds make their records available for audit. Additionally, they must encourage economic vitality consistent with the Heritage Area. The local coordinating entity is prohibited from acquiring real property or interests in real property with Federal funds or through condemnation, in line with the Heritage Area guidelines. SEC. 7. RELATIONSHIP TO OTHER FEDERAL AGENCIES. In General, this Act does not affect a Federal agency's authority to provide assistance under other laws. Federal agencies planning activities impacting the Heritage Area should consult with the Secretary and local entity. This Act does not modify laws authorizing Federal land management or limit a land manager's discretion within the Heritage Area boundaries. PRIVATE PROPERTY AND REGULATORY PROTECTIONS. The Act does not limit property owners' rights or require public access to their property. It also does not change any existing land use regulations or authorities. The curr_chunk outlines restrictions on any Federal, State, tribal, or local government actions within the Heritage Area, including limitations on altering treaty rights, water rights, wildlife management, private property liability, and grazing permits on Federal lands. The curr_chunk specifies restrictions on water projects within the Heritage Area, including construction, operation, maintenance, and expansion of water storage and delivery systems on Federal lands. SEC. 9. CLARIFICATION: The Act does not allow the Secretary to allocate or distribute Federal funds to the local coordinating entity or spend Federal funds for purposes not specified in the Act. 

SEC. 10. TERMINATION OF AUTHORITY: The Secretary's authority to provide assistance under this Act ends 15 years after its enactment.
